Cividale del Friuli is a small jewel in the far north-eastern corner of Italy. Traditional histories say that it was founded by Julius Caesar, who gave the town its first recorded name: Forum Iulii (which has now become the name of Cividale's region, Friuli -unofficial capital of Friuli is

). Archeologists, however, have found remains of older Celtic settlements. 
In the Middle Ages, Cividale become a capital of the Lombards. The town now
site celebrates its Lombard heritage. Cividale was the seat of the Patriarch of Aquilea (as that Roman city had been destroyed by Huns) until the 1200s, when the Patriarchs moved to

.
In June 2011, Cividale and six other cities of the Lombards together were named a collective UNESCO World Heritage Site, Italia Langobardorum: Cividale del Friuli (
),Benevento and Monte Sant'Angelo (Foggia). The recognition rewards Cividale's remarkable medieval treasures.

value: content=Part of "Longobards in Italy, Places of Power" set of buildings which is on the UNESCO World Heritage list.
